ReSTIR (Reservoir-Based SpatioTemporal Importance Resampling)

Reservoir-Based Importance Resampling

Importance Sampling

By 13.10 Importance Sampling of "PBR Book V3" and "2.2.2 Importance Sampling" of "PBR Book V4", for f is always non-negative, when the proposal distribution PDF p is proportional to f (namely, p ( X ) = f ( X ) ∥ f ∥ 1 \displaystyle \mathop{\mathrm{p}} (X) = \frac{\displaystyle \mathop{\mathrm{f}} (X)}{\displaystyle {\| f \|}_1} p(X)=∥f∥1​f(X)​), the variance is zero and only one sample is sufficient.

Reservoir Sampling

Basic Reservoir Sampling

By "A.2 Reservoir Sampling" of "PBR Book V4", we have the basic reservoir sampling.

We sequentially process each sample from the stream. The total length of the stream can indeed be infinite which is too large to be stored in the memory.

We assume that we have processed n samples. This means that the number of the seen samples is n. For the basic reservoir sampling, the reservoir can hold at most 1 reservoir sample, and the first 1 seen sample is always selected to initialize the reservoir. For each subsequent seen candidate sample, we have the probability 1 n \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} n1​ of selecting it to replace the existing sample within the reservoir.

We can prove by mathematical Induction that at any iteration, when we have processed n samples, each sample from the stream has the equal probability 1 n \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} n1​ of being included in the final reservoir.

Base Case

At the iteration, when we have processed n = 1 sample, each sample has the equal probability 1 1 = 1 \displaystyle \frac{1}{1} = 1 11​=1 of being included in the final reservoir.

Inductive Step

We assume that at the t-th iteration, when we have processed n = t samples, each sample from the stream has the equal probability 1 t \displaystyle \frac{1}{t} t1​ of being included in the final reservoir.

And we would like to prove that at the (t + 1)-th iteration, when we have processed n = t + 1 samples, each sample from the stream has the equal probability 1 t + 1 \displaystyle \frac{1}{t + 1} t+11​ of being included in the final reservoir.

Evidently, the (t + 1)-th seen sample has the probability 1 t + 1 \displaystyle \frac{1}{t + 1} t+11​ of being selected to replace the existing sample within the reservoir and thus being included in the final reservoir.

For the previous t seen samples, they have the probability 1 t \displaystyle \frac{1}{t} t1​ of being included in the final reservoir at t-th iteration. At the same time, they have the probability 1 − 1 t + 1 = t t + 1 \displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{t + 1} = \frac{t}{t + 1} 1−t+11​=t+1t​ of NOT being replaced by the (t + 1)-th seen sample at (t + 1)-th iteration. This means that they have the probability 1 t × t t + 1 = 1 t + 1 \displaystyle \frac{1}{t} \times \frac{t}{t + 1} = \frac{1}{t + 1} t1​×t+1t​=t+11​ of being included in the final reservoir at (t + 1)-th iteration.

K-Sized Reservoir Sampling

The difference is that the reservoir can hold at most k (instead of 1) reservoir sample, and the first k (instead of 1) seen sample is always selected to initialize the reservoir. For each subsequent seen candidate sample, we have the probability k n \displaystyle \frac{k}{n} nk​ (instead of 1 n \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} n1​) of selecting it to replace the existing sample within the reservoir.

When we have processed n samples, each sample from the stream has the equal probability k n \displaystyle \frac{k}{n} nk​ (instead of 1 n \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} n1​) of being included in the final reservoir.

Weighted Reservoir Sampling

By "A.2 Reservoir Sampling" of "PBR Book V4", we have the weighted reservoir sampling.

The difference is that each seen sample has the probability according to the weight (instead of the constant k n \displaystyle \frac{k}{n} nk​) of being selected to replace the existing sample within the reservoir.

Each sample from the stream has the probability proportional to the weight of being included in the final reservoir.
